H0.text: Weathering and erosion are the processes most responsible for the decrease in the height of the Appalachian Mountains, which extend from Canada to Alabama and were much taller in the past than they are today.

H1.text: Sedimentation and flooding are the two processes most responsible for the decrease in height of the Appalachian Mountains, which extend from Canada to Alabama and were much taller in the past than they are today.

H2.text: Volcanic eruptions and landslides are the two processes most responsible for the decrease in the height of the Appalachian Mountains, which extend from Canada to Alabama and were much taller in the past than they are today.

H3.text: Tectonic collisions and earthquakes are the two processes most responsible for the decrease in the height of the Appalachian Mountains, which extend from Canada to Alabama and were much taller in the past than they are today.

A4.text: Weathering is a crucial part of the rock cycle; sedimentary rock, the product of weathered rock, covers 66% of the Earth's continents and much of the ocean floor.

A5.text: The process of mountain block uplift is important in exposing new rock strata to the atmosphere and moisture, enabling important chemical weathering to occur; significant release occurs of Ca2+ and other ions into surface waters.
